title: Cotherstone Moor
text:
Cotherstone Moor is a <a href="Site%20of%20Special%20Scientific%20Interest">Site of Special Scientific Interest</a> in the <a href="Teesdale%20%28district%29">Teesdale</a> district in south-west <a href="County%20Durham">County Durham</a>, <a href="England">England</a>. It is an extensive area of <a href="moorland">moorland</a> which extends almost the entire length of <a href="Baldersdale">Baldersdale</a>, from the confluence of the <a href="River%20Balder">River Balder</a> with the <a href="River%20Tees">Tees</a> at <a href="Cotherstone">Cotherstone</a>. It runs parallel to <a href="Bowes%20Moor">Bowes Moor</a> SSSI, which lies a short distance to the south.
The area includes a variety of upland vegetation types, much of it <a href="blanket%20bog">blanket bog</a>, including one area that is found nowhere else in County Durham and which is unusual for being transitional between northern upland and lowland bogs. Other habitats include dry <a href="Heath%20%28habitat%29">heath</a>, acid grassland, <a href="Poor%20fen%23Ecology">flushes</a>, and rock and block <a href="scree">scree</a>.
The area supports breeding populations of a number of species of birds that are listed in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>'s <a href="Regional%20Red%20List">Red Data Book (Birds)</a>, including four that are listed in Annex 1 of the European Commission's <a href="Birds%20Directive">Birds Directive</a> as requiring special protection.
The <a href="Pennine%20Way">Pennine Way</a> <a href="National%20Trail">National Trail</a> passes through the area.
